text: Questioner pushes back, says anything less than single payer props up rapacious industry. Buttigieg now sketching out the different kinds of universal coverage. "The definition of socialism, especially on some news networks, is: Anything proposed by Democrats that we don't like."
author: daveweigel

text: to a Medicare for All Q: "Any politician who talks about Medicare for All has a responsibility to talk about the road to get there." First step is public option.
author: daveweigel

text: Buttigieg, asked about Citizens United, says that "Supreme court reform" is one option, but "if it's true that the Constitution won't allow that, then how about an amendment?" Later: "This country changed the Constitution so that you couldn't drink. And then it changed it back!"
author: daveweigel

text: Asked about guns, Buttigieg refers to his military service: "I learned a skill for the purpose of defending myself in a war zone... some of these weapons of war have no place in peacetime in American neighborhoods."
author: daveweigel

text: ooooooof
author: daveweigel

text: Asked about immigration, Buttigieg points out that his family immigrated from "a place where Buttigieg is a common name." Says that there clearly is a legislative path to immigration reform, got blocked by politics, which is why "democracy is issue one."
author: daveweigel

text: Another big @PeteButtigieg crowd in Rock Hill, SC. Can’t be said enough how much interest there is in these candidates this early, compared to previous cycles.
author: daveweigel

text: Hva med din gaffes?
author: daveweigel

text: Yoko and me, that’s reality
author: daveweigel

text: Cory Booker talking up his college debt forgiveness plan, in which people in some occupations get debt wiped out first. “f you are a teacher in this country, you should not have to pay this onerous college debt.”
author: daveweigel

text: Two miles away from the Buttigieg event, the OTHER Rhodes scholar in the race, Cory Booker, is speaking at an EITC event. Very few black faces at the Buttigieg rally, lots of black faces here.
author: daveweigel

text: A Norwegian outlet is here and asked @PeteButtigieg to speak the language. And he did!
author: daveweigel

text: Asked @PeteButtigieg why he’s not going to AIPAC. “I wasn’t invited!” He doesn’t rule out going in future.
author: daveweigel

text: Respectfully, I was paraphrasing the Q because I needed the space. Full Q was about whether he thought anything could be in the report that got Republicans to dump Trump; several other 2020 Dems have suggested Trump may not even be the nominee.
author: daveweigel

text: Need to see the long form participation trophy certificate
author: daveweigel

text: "A month ago, it felt like no one knew who I was. Now, it feels like people are starting to know who I am."
author: daveweigel

text: That was why I quoted the whole thing!
author: daveweigel

author: daveweigel

text: Lots of wealthy liberals funded the effort to overturn Florida's felon voting ban. Soros gave $1.5 million. I'm unaware of any Schultz donation.
author: daveweigel

text: Also, abolishing the electoral college usually polls well. If they’re using time that could be spent talking Medicare they’re... using it to discuss something fairly popular.
author: daveweigel

text: McConnell has also attacked HR1 on floor speeches so it’s not like he thinks it’s a cool easy vote for Ds

text: strong broken brain energy in this tweet
author: daveweigel

text: Side note: I think the “AIPAC boycott” is overstated. No one is ruling out going in 2020.

text: In conclusion: BABA BOOEY
author: daveweigel

text: While they’re at it, maybe they could correctly guess the number of marbles in a jar or name every county judge.
author: daveweigel

text: if you need a blurb from a neolib shill you have my email
author: daveweigel

text: What always bugged me about the "tarmac meeting forced Comey's hand" stuff: If, indeed, Bill Clinton wanted to pressure Lynch, there's a thing called a "telephone" he could have used, harder to trace than a meeting with a bunch of witnesses.
author: daveweigel

text: Interesting @PeteButtigieg answer on whether Mueller findings could end the Trump presidency. Short answer: Not really!
author: daveweigel

text: Interesting comparison here is the 2016 probe of Hillary's email practices. Lots of speculation that she'd be indicted. When she wasn't, GOP pulled Comey in for a hearing about why, and messaging became "different set of rules for Clinton."
author: daveweigel

text: Unpopular opinion: Gibney always has amazing interviews and primary sources but the finished films are a little rote.
author: daveweigel

text: A lot of these Twitter arguments seem to be about cable TV, which indeed has been fire w Russia coverage, rehabilitated people like Brennan, etc. I'm just saying, the "Dems will count on Russiagate to save them" stuff has been wrong.
author: daveweigel

text: The best argument by the “Russigate is a waste of time” folks was that Dems would wait for a deux ex machina to unseat Trump, and not examine why they had lost. Totally wrong, it turns out.
author: daveweigel

text: Buttigieg is canvassing w Tina Belge, a young state senate candidate here. A group of girls just walked by and asked why cameras were following: “Oh, we thought it was a prom-posal video.”
author: daveweigel

text: Have any of the "Dems are obsessed with Russia and Trump" pundits noticed how much policy is actually getting discussed in this primary?
author: daveweigel

text: Talking to Dem voters about Mueller, and struck by how even the diehards who’ve been obsessing over it assume that it won’t lead to him being impeached or forced out. Very nuanced. Need more Twitter style rage and anger.
author: daveweigel

text: #Buttigang
author: daveweigel

text:
Two funny things about that:

1) Pelosi’s getting unanimous Dem support on basically every bill, so everyone is like 90% w AOC

2) The GOP motions to recommit are allowing some swing seat Dems to cut that number — complete w attacks from AOC!
author: daveweigel

text: Buttigieg notes that Mike Pence is coming to the state to help the GOP candidate running in the special election here. “I think you all know how I feel about my former Governor. Helps me understand how you feel about that whole Lindsey Graham thing.”
author: daveweigel

text: Buttigieg has some fun with how rambling that intro was; “I’m always ready for a detailed legislative update!”
author: daveweigel

text:
“What I am going to do — what we are all going to do — is count to three. We’re going to count one, two, three. And we’re gonna say, Mayor Pete. We’re gonna hear from someone who...” (restates his biography)

This is like the Coen bros wrote a long winded politician character
author: daveweigel

text: “I know you didn’t come here to see me,” he jokes, before two minutes (so far) of an introduction of Buttigieg (who has to leave in like 5 minutes).
author: daveweigel

text: The life of the underdog candidate: Buttigieg waiting to speak after a local state senator who’s on minute 16 of a “brief legislative update.” (The crowd laughed when he said “one more thing,” which was two “one more things” ago.)
author: daveweigel

text: It was actually the latest Dem candidate, Senator Pete-John Buttilooper.
author: daveweigel

text: The real “whuh” moment here is Nunes referring to “authoritarianism” to describe... House Democrats passing legislation without GOP support.
author: daveweigel

text: Fun demonstration of how our political movements diverge: watch left Twitter react to Mueller (lol libs will be let down, it was all a sham), then watch the president’s base continue to talk about Hillary (gotta keep investigating bc something will come up).
author: daveweigel

text: Pete Buttigieg kicking off a day of campaigning with a classic candidate ritual.
author: daveweigel

text: Congrats to everyone who correctly said “Lindsey Graham.”
author: daveweigel

text:
The joke is that he is your brother.

(Seriously, though, you’re a great reporter but this is the best name blindness meme ever.)
author: daveweigel

text: Sad day for your family.
author: daveweigel

text: Mueller Phase I-XIV
author: daveweigel

text: @ryanlcooper buying one for you
author: daveweigel

text: Who’s gonna be first with the “now that Mueller’s work is complete, the time has come to investigate the FBI’s 2016 probe of Hillary Clinton” press release?
author: daveweigel

text: Hot take: The Mueller report is more problematic for Ds than Rs. We know what Rs will do unless the report is devastating: Defend the president. But Ds have been punting Qs about impeachment etc until the report was done.
author: daveweigel

text: Post-town hall scrum w Tulsi Gabbard. I asked if she was attending AIPAC conference (no, but not for political reasons) and the DCCC anti-primary policy (against). Michael Tracey asked if the Mueller report was distracting people from the issues that matter.
author: daveweigel

text: The “friends we made along the way” joke is pretty played out, huh? In that case, I have no Mueller Report jokes. Enjoy your Friday!
author: daveweigel

text: @kenklippenstein fix this
author: daveweigel

text: One thing I miss about Filmstruck was the app -- I watched most of the movies on my iPad. Will there be a @criterionchannl app?
author: daveweigel

text: I think the "socialism" storyline got a lot of extra gas because Schultz got free media to insist that his former party (not just Sanders, AOC) had become hopelessly socialist. Probably the biggest free media gift to Trump this year.
author: daveweigel

text: Twitter is obviously argument city, but the actual Dem *candidates* have refused to go negative on each other. Schultz is filling that gap, with endless attacks on Democrats (and fairly rote criticism of Trump).
author: daveweigel

text: Related: I find that Warren's audiences, more than other candidates', comment on the way out that they were surprised at how "down to earth" she was.
author: daveweigel

text:
Quote in @danielmarans's story reminds me: Sanders's 2016 campaign was remarkable, but it got fewer votes than Hillary '16, Hillary '08, and Obama '08.

The idea that the base won't show up for another candidate is flawed.

https://www.huffpost.com/entry/beto-orourke-bernie-sanders-democratic-fundraising-primary_n_5c941176e4b01ebeef0d1cae?fbclid=IwAR3VKDfSZOmy5kFJGL7ItbjyB7BHwXJymyrvW5VE_VUuplJUhcWuB-xqhok …
author: daveweigel

text: That said: The fossil fuel pledge *allows* employees of energy cos to give money. The prohibition is on PACs and large donations from executives.
author: daveweigel

text: When I asked @JayInslee (who has a super PAC) about it, his argument was basically: Look, if a second Trump term is an existential threat, how many impediments do you want to create for your campaign to beat him?
author: daveweigel

text: Detecting the start of a backlash to this Q. Dems who have waved away a bunch money (and nixed super PACs) still getting birddogged by activists who want them to make more pledges. Meanwhile no GOP base demands on incumbent POTUS as he piles up cash.
author: daveweigel

text: Getting rid of the electoral college also means creating a system where this map isn’t enough to reaffirm the sovereignty of House Atreides.
author: daveweigel

text: Sorry for the manual RT, I just figured that was the way to explain this to people who’d have strong opinions.
author: daveweigel

text:
The local Fox affiliate in Randolph, NH is owned by Sinclair, so I learned that the must-run Boris commentary refers to Beto O'Rourke as "Robert O'Rourke." 

I checked and, no, he does not refer to the man who defeated O'Rourke as Rafael Cruz.
author: daveweigel

text: I always thought it weird that Paul Ryan was seen as the man who could save the GOP from Trump as we learned in 2012 that his economic agenda couldn't win national elections. Just got memory-holed for some reason.
author: daveweigel

text: I didn't realize how old I was until I carpooled with some twentysomething reporters in Illinois in 2016. Saw a sign for Aurora, pointed it out to them, and they had no idea what Wayne's World was.

text: Do you watch “You’re the Worst?” It’s not for everyone but there was a joke last season about the ellipsis that appears when someone is texting back and it was one of the funniest things I saw all year.

That’s a real thing that happens in the movie.

The Obama comparison is not facile -- he lets the words floooow. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/paloma/the-trailer/2019/03/21/the-trailer-what-we-learned-about-beto-for-america-this-week/5c9299201b326b0f7f38f20e/?utm_term=.e8571562cf76 …

text: re the SCOTUS stuff, whatever one thinks of adding to the size of the court, the Constitution leaves it entirely up to Congress/POTUS. It's Republicans who are introducing actual constitutional amendments to cap the court at 9.

author: daveweigel

text: Worth noting here: Traditionally, prez candidates don't give speeches at AIPAC except in election years. But they often talk to closed-press sessions. Harris has done so before.
author: daveweigel

text: I once referred to Cheri Bustos as a member from "southwest Illinois" and I still hear about it
author: daveweigel

text:
Sounds like Rep. Abigail Spanberger handled the "what about the socialists?" Q the same way Rep. Max Rose did: She embraced the contrast. 

Republicans can't defy Trump and hold onto their base. Democrats feel no such pressure to align with AOC.
https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/campaigns/cia-officer-turned-lawmaker-dismisses-threat-to-fall-in-line-or-face-primary-challenge …
author: daveweigel

text: The gap between DNC and RNC messaging these days reminds me of that Onion cover about the 1980 election: "Let's Talk Better Mileage" vs "Kill the Bastards." From last 24 hours...
author: daveweigel

text: Headline from March 2023: "Biden mulls Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as out-of-the-gate running mate."
author: daveweigel

text: Really glad they’re delaying @swin24’s trial in The Hague so he can write this
author: daveweigel

text: Especially because Bernie is even older and never hints at this! (At the same time, Bernie’s presence in the race is making it easier for Biden to sell the “old guy you can trust” image.)
author: daveweigel

text: Typical east coast elitism. Talk to any voter in a rust belt diner and he’ll tell you: “I know who George Conway is, have strong opinions about him, and want his tweets covered to the exclusion of other topics.”
author: daveweigel

text: The “one term rescue mission” concept sounds gimmicky (and is!) but I wouldn’t underestimate the number of Dems whose only issue is getting Trump out of there.
author: daveweigel

text: February 31, 2020
author: daveweigel

text:
Big applause when Beto says he’s not taking PAC money.

One activist I talked to yesterday was frustrated that they people seem satisfied by “no corporate PAC” pledges when they see huge loopholes for special interests and wealthy donors.
author: daveweigel

text: Beto addressing the overflow crowd. Nobody left after realizing they could see him if they just hung out in the (normal winter) cold
author: daveweigel

text: Beto’s “let’s put on a show” style of campaigning sets him apart, but has downsides. Most of the people who showed up for his Portsmouth event (even 30 min early) are outside shivering.
author: daveweigel

text: Keep in mind that Bernie is competing with a Dem idea (maybe wrong) that Biden is the safest choice if you want to win. I don’t think a 51-49 poll like this helps too much.
author: daveweigel

text:
Is it rude to point out that Hillary Clinton led Trump in the popular vote by the same margin?

The “Bernie would have won” argument is a big factor in the primaries. But it’s based on 2016 polls that suggested Sanders would clobber Trump, not narrowly lead him.
author: daveweigel

text: The best kind of bad tweet is the one written by someone who thinks they NAILED it
author: daveweigel

text: I am still wrapping my head around the "skimping on a woman" line. Is the argument that health care isn't good unless the bill is really high?
author: daveweigel

text: Among the mysteries of this poll: Gillibrand won a landslide re-election four months ago, and her approval rating in NY is now 29/35.
author: daveweigel

text: hola amigos
author: daveweigel

text:
Today, like every day, was stupid, so I want to conduct a poll about something stupider.

Who was the best classic Onion columnist?
author: daveweigel

text: Whom amongst us
author: daveweigel

text: Beto also always refers to the next president as "he or she." Can't think of the last POTUS candidate who implied from outset that he/she could lose the nomination.
author: daveweigel

text: The easiest Q for Beto to answer is, funny enough, how he did so well in TX and whether he could scale that nationally. (Nobody seems to mind that he lost!) Answer: He went everywhere. "We went to counties so red you could see them glowing, from space."
author: daveweigel

text: Missed this while on Beto duty but apparently POTUS thinks high union dues forced GM's hand on Lordstown? I... don't understand.
author: daveweigel

text:
Another Q: "Do you support a UBI similar to the one proposed by @AndrewYang?" (Yes, Yang was cited by name.)

Beto does not, starts talking about paying people more for the work they do.
author: daveweigel

text: One of her sub-questions was about BDS... Beto appears to be avoiding an answer on that. (It was a very smart Q but there's always a risk with two- or three-part Qs that the pol won't handle them all.)
author: daveweigel

text: A Palestinian immigrant asks a multi-part Israel Q. Beto says he supports a two-state solution, is unsure if there are willing partners. "We know that in PM Netanyahu, we have someone who has openly sided with racists in that country."
author: daveweigel

text: First Q in Durham is whether he'll pledge not to take $ from "the fossil fuel industry." Beto: "I will not take a dime from a PAC or lobbyist, no matter who or what they represent." (That leaves an escape hatch, as Beto has been hit for taking $ from energy industry employees)
author: daveweigel

text: ie "I have no hope of earning your vote; no hope of prevailing in this primary; no hope of defeating President Trump" without coming to hear the audience's concerns. 2/2
author: daveweigel

text: I'm at Beto's final NH event of the day. Every Dem has a different rhetorical style. Bernie's is "line" (applause) "line" (applause). Beto's is an argument with a series of semicolons... 1/2
author: daveweigel

text: "Why isn't the media covering X" = "Why is X not currently on the cable news channel I am watching?"
author: daveweigel

text: He has had a ton of bad ideas that get rolled into “he has experience”
author: daveweigel

text: It was a multi part q
author: daveweigel

text: This is a heck of a take on the anniversary of the 2003 Iraq invasion. (Didn’t go so great for the last Dem w national security experience who voted for the war.)
author: daveweigel

text: I asked Beto about his support of means testing entitlements in 2012. “I’ve gotten smarter since then,” he said. He had conversations w constituents and colleagues that convinced him that you can raise the cap and pay for Social Security w/o benefit cuts.
author: daveweigel

text:
Q: Andrew Gillum said today that you enjoy some privileges that other candidates don’t have. What’s your response?

Beto: Yes.
author: daveweigel

text: Toughest Q for Beto at this event so far is what accomplishments he can point to: After running down some bipartisan bills, he talks about how his Senate campaign drove up turnout.
author: daveweigel

text: It's not an "issue* Q per se, but I heard it here and hear it a lot: How do you get young people to vote? Beto keeps repeating that young voter turnout was up 500% in 2018 over 2014 (in Texas), which gets lots of applause.
author: daveweigel

text: A stage! Not as visually stimulating.
author: daveweigel

text: Biggest reaction at this Conway, NH Beto event is when he reels out his voting reform ideas -- understandable given NH's perennial fight over student voting and ID.
author: daveweigel

text:
It was the wrong link! Meant to use this one. 

Neither the light nor the iPhone6s is very good for photography, sadly.
author: daveweigel

text: The NRCC asked what she was referring to. I asked her office what she was referring to; she said, via a tweet, that she was referring to Russia. Story's over, ttyl.
author: daveweigel

text: My first Beto O’Rourke campaign event! (Seriously. I was the only reporter in the Western Hemisphere who did not profile his 2018 race.)
author: daveweigel

text: It's the only answer that makes sense. Unless you're arguing that the congresswoman who took her Jewish husband's last name was secretly arguing that Israel is working to divide Americans.
author: daveweigel

text: A coda to the NRCC's "is Jennifer Wexton an anti-Semite?" attack, one of the more ridiculous things I've dealt with this year...
author: daveweigel

text: I swear to G-d that I find it boring. Keep in mind, I find 15-minute drum solos exciting.
author: daveweigel

text: Btw the “did she mean Israel?” response never made sense. The anti-Semitic argument is that Israel runs US foreign policy and demands unanimity, not that it’s trying to divide Americans.
author: daveweigel

text: Because I thought I was being too broad.
author: daveweigel

text: 2019 in a nutshell. A Dem attacks “foreign governments” that want to divide Americans. She means Russia; GOP asks whether she’s an anti-Semite who was talking about Israel.
author: daveweigel

text: Yes, I was struck by how loopy some of the "show us the donations" stuff got. The idea that he had some Texas D or rich donor transfer really got around.
author: daveweigel

text: I haven't thought about this recently but it rings true. It took a *very* long time for conservative media to process that Obama was going to beat the Clintons.
author: daveweigel

text:
Third time O'Rourke has been asked about late-term abortion or something similar. Two observations.

1) He's getting the Q bc he's taking a ton of Qs and doesn't seem to be screening. Good, IMO.

2) He's totally dodging, but any adroit candidate would.
author: daveweigel

text: Sure, I'm just explaining why nobody in the room on Sunday heard "anti-Semitism" or criticism of Israel in that answer. When Democrats in 2019 hear "foreign governments trying to divide" they think Russia.
author: daveweigel

text:
The "Bernie would have won" cohort is invested in the idea that he's the most popular politician in America -- which was true in 2017 but hasn't been recently.

Bigger problem for Ds is that *none* of their candidates are as popular as their 2008 field.
author: daveweigel

text: Manchin/Moulton 2020 would probably win if the election were held today, while simultaneously making Twitter explode.
author: daveweigel

text: Including Hillary’s vote for it, which led to Obama beating her
author: daveweigel

text: The other day, a passenger on a plane got FURIOUS with me because, as soon as we landed, I made a phone call. Was this passenger’s irritation
author: daveweigel

text: Yes, it's always good to ask for clarification. I just think (sincerely, even though this is Twitter) that lobbing "anti-Semitism" like this is irresponsible. In the room, everyone heard it as a reference to foreign bots etc.
author: daveweigel

text: The quote was sent by the NRCC with the subject "is Jennifer Wexton an anti-Semite, too?" and a suggestion, not in the quote, that she was attacking Israel. Come on.
author: daveweigel

text: Also, I was in the room, and it's quite a stretch to think Wexton was blaming Israel for anything. The quote:
author: daveweigel

text: Increasingly likely that Chicago will elect a black, gay, female mayor in 13 days. (It only recently became legal to elect a mayor not named “Daley”)

Red states probably pass amendment to kill electoral college by breakfast the next day.

text: France has a two-round system that, in 2017, prevented the far right FN from winning. Got most votes in first round but was demolished in runoff.
author: daveweigel

text: It was well known that FDR had polio, but voters were misled into thinking he had largely recovered his mobility. He gave speeches propped up, for example.
author: daveweigel

text: Actually a bunch of electoral systems allow this; the only ones that completely prevent it have runoff systems, like France, or modified proportional representation, like Germany.
author: daveweigel

text: Got deja vu from this, then remembered why: I was filming this exchange from a different.m angle! https://twitter.com/mikegravel/status/1108362768518955008?s=21 … https://youtu.be/NbxMWfCW5ag

text: Massachusetts is so irrelevant to national campaigns that Rs don’t merely avoid it — they make fun of it. Think of Dick Armey joking that Dems held their 2004 convention in Boston “instead of somewhere like America.”

text: The whole “Hillary’s sick and could die soon” meme was all over social media in 2016. Hillary was 69 on Election Day; Biden will be 77 and Sanders will be 79 on Election Day 2020. https://twitter.com/hey_itsthatguy/status/1108356596919353345?s=21 …

text: National horse race polling doesn’t mean much — just name ID before most voters tune in. But I think there’s something in these numbers about candidates and age. The two leaders in Dem polls are simply older than voters say they’re comfortable with.

text: After defending his vote on the GOP's ICE amendment, Rose explains why he opposed the HR1 amendment to ban undocumented immigrants from voting. "It's already illegal... they were afraid to vote on anti-corruption legislation, so they decided to play games."
author: daveweigel

text: Probably the most popular Q of the night: Is there a way to stop spammers from using fake phone numbers so people can block them? "You shouldn't be harassed by private companies. We gotta figure out a way to do that."
author: daveweigel

text: Don’t listen to him Cathy
author: daveweigel

text:
Q: Is Congress going to get to see an un-redacted version of the Mueller report?

Rose: Ohhhhhhh, we better.
author: daveweigel

text: Rose asked about the GOP's amendment that would notify ICE if undocumented immigrants try to buy guns. "If someone is buying a weapon who shouldn’t be, authorities should be notified," he says. Then he defends "sanctuary cities" and unloads on ICE for "over-stepping its bounds."
author: daveweigel

text: Rose gets asked about born-alive abortion bill; Rose answers by describing situation where a doctor informs a woman that the pregnancy will kill her. "If you think I’m gonna get in the middle of that discussion, you’re out of your damn mind."
author: daveweigel

text: Asked about border wall, Rose points out that vast majority of undocumented immigrants are overstaying visas, and that drugs/terrorists are apprehended at points of entry. Won't "sacrifice our values" to support a border wall (but did support some fencing money).
author: daveweigel

text:
Getting some “this is why Dems lose” response to these Max Rose live tweets.

Worth noting: Hillary won 43.8% of the vote in this district. Rose flipped it with 53.0%.
author: daveweigel

text: I've always thought of @LizMair as "the thinking man's @DevinNunesMom."
author: daveweigel

text: One of Rose's biggest applause lines so far: "Under no circumstances will the VA be privatized."
author: daveweigel

text: Rose is making a populist defense of unions, attacking tax cuts for rich and wage theft, talking up affordable housing and an assault weapons ban. And he's also attacking "socialism." Big tent in action.
author: daveweigel

text: But on Green New Deal itself, Rose is a no: "It takes a socialist economic agenda and puts it under the veil of environmentalism. That's not who I am."
author: daveweigel

text: Asked about Green New Deal, Rose says he favors "generations-long infrastructure project to transition our economy, responsibly, to a carbon-free system." Has also been talking up money for flood walls in NYC.
author: daveweigel

text: Rep. Max Rose (D-NY) at his first town hall: “I have to make a confession: I’m not a socialist. I’m not an anti-Semite... I was the first member of the Democratic Party to come out and criticize what I saw as an anti-Semitic remark.”

text: One of those moments where you see the culture clash in full color. You could tell this constituent -- jaw clenched, storming out afterward -- was genuinely offended that Wexton was not flying a POW flag, and he overstated the # of POWS (1,589) by a factor of 10.
author: daveweigel

text: Wexton says it's a "community that's under attack and needs our support." What she does not say, but could, is that she has a transgender kid in the family, who was invited to House swearing-in day. 2/2
author: daveweigel

text: Definitely the first time I've heard this Q: A frustrated-sounding constituent (who video records the exchange and leaves right after) asks why Wexton is hanging a transgender flag instead of a POW flag outside her office. 1/2
author: daveweigel

text: I'm at Rep. Jennifer Wexton's first town hall. One constituent criticizes Ds as "puppets" for Pelosi during SOTU. Wexton: "When [Trump] said he'd make an unprecedented investment in child cancer research, I was proud to stand up and applaud. But his budget doesn't do that."
author: daveweigel

text: He ran for governor in 2006 as the Green candidate and had an ad that could not have used more than one take
author: daveweigel

text: Biden previewing a campaign theme: "We need a new corporate ethic in America. You're gonna hear a lot more about it from me."
author: daveweigel

text: Biden's closing (unless he goes over 30 minutes) riff is star-spangled stuff about American greatness. "It's an idea that's stronger than any army, more powerful than any ocean, bigger than any dictator."
author: daveweigel

text: This was also @ChrisCoons's argument for Biden: He's got the Obama record to run on, so let's see some other Dem argue he had more progressive wins than that. (Coons said it more politely.)
author: daveweigel

text: Biden moved on fast from whatever he was saying about the new left after that slip, focusing on Trump. "If you asked me a few years ago whether our democracy could ever crumble, I would have laughed at you."
author: daveweigel

text: Biden now doing that the thing where he goes from a low rumble to A BIG YELL, attacking Trump for his Charlottesville remarks. "The world's worst dictators are using his own words to justify his own abuse of power."
author: daveweigel

text: Biden almost slips up! He says he gets "criticized by the new left," then says "I have the most progressive record of anybody running..." He stops himself and kind of hem-haws as the crowd gets up and cheers.
author: daveweigel

text: Biden talking about Delaware's tradition of "returns day," a post-election parade which ends when the winners and losers literally bury a hatchet together. "They know about it in Mumbai. They know about it in London. They know about it in Beijing."
author: daveweigel

text: Biden on a riff now about how politics has become too personal: "When the man who sits next to you, a Republican, is crying because his wife has breast cancer, it’s awfully hard to dislike that man."
author: daveweigel

text: Biden referring repeatedly to "Barack," as in "As Michelle writes in her book, Joe was like Barack’s big brother."
author: daveweigel

text: "I've been in the excess of 80 nations... and I always talk about Delaware. We don't demonize our opponents. We don't belittle them. We don't treat the opposition as the enemy. We might even say a nice word about a Republican if they do something good."
author: daveweigel

text: Biden praising Rep. Blunt Rochester: "She's one of the best new leaders in the House of Representatives. That's not hyperbole." Bidenism count: 2.
author: daveweigel

text:
Biden talking a lot about Beau, his late son: "You know you're a success when you look at your child and know he turned out better than you."

He used that line at the 2008 DNC and followed with "I'm a success. I'm a hell of a success!"

Tonight: "Beau was better than me."
author: daveweigel

text: Biden's on stage, and we have our first Bidenism 90 seconds in: "I'm serious. Not a joke."
author: daveweigel

text: Gov. John Carney: "Joe doesn't just look like he's back. He looks like he's ready for a fight."
author: daveweigel

text: *learned not shaped
author: daveweigel

text: One of tonight's activist award winners, Sonia Schorr Sloan, tells the audience that she's worked in every Biden campaign and told him "I have one more campaign left in me."
author: daveweigel

text: "We know Joe. Literally every single one of us."
author: daveweigel

text: Coons has a way of referring to negatives that Biden does *not* have but it's never clear who, if anyone, he is referring to. "He hasn't just shaped history on some college campus. He's changed history."
author: daveweigel

text:
Coons keeps describing a future president "who unites and us and heals us."

"Folks, I am praying for that man, and I am excited to hear from him a few moments from now."
author: daveweigel

text: Sen. Chris Coons on 2020: "We will show the country and the world that what happened in 2016 was an aberration."
author: daveweigel

text: Carper closes by congratulating 2018 primary foe @KerriHarrisDE on being elected a DNC committee member. "We have a new committee member and her name is... Harris! Kerri Evelyn Harris! Are you out there?" (She is in the very back of the room.)
author: daveweigel

text: Carper's using his remarks to talk about non-wall border security, praising Biden for addressing "the lack of hope and opportunity" and supporting Plan Colombia. "Give Joe Biden a round of applause. He wrote that!"
author: daveweigel

text:
Sen. Tom Carper addresses Biden in the audience as "President Biden," then half-jokes that Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester (who he refers to as "young, brown") should be his running mate.

Carper's 2018 opponent, Kerri Harris, is in the audience.
author: daveweigel

text: How we know we're not at a Trump rally: LBR adds "the media in the back" to her list of "heroes and sheroes" saving the country.
author: daveweigel

text: The Bidenphilia is coming fast and furious at the Delaware Dem dinner -- even when he's not named, speakers seem to be referring to him in the audience. Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester (D-Del.) talking 2020: "We cannot blow this moment. This is our moment, Delaware Democrats."
author: daveweigel

text: “All those people hate me, so I must be doing something right” is an okay affirmation for, like, a hot take writer. But if you’re trying to get elected to something...
author: daveweigel

text: It’s in the interest of many current political actors to say that the DNC forced an unelectable Clinton on the party, but at this point four years ago elected Dems looked at how she drubbed Obama with white voters in 2008 and assumed she could mend ties with them.
author: daveweigel

text: Both Biden and Sanders benefit from polling that showed — in a vacuum where they faced no GOP attacks — that they would have won in 2016. Echoing in my brain: the Dems who pointed to Clinton’s 2008 primary strength to say she was a winner for 2016.
author: daveweigel

text: The Bernie theory of holding mass rallies in favor of widely popular legislation doesn’t really get past McConnell’s “don’t allow votes on things” strategy.
author: daveweigel

text:
My election nerd quibble with Rahm here is that he cites (but does not name) Bob Kerrey as an example of why Dems need a message that can win red states.

Kerrey made a comeback bid for Senate in 2012. Same moderate message. Lost by 16 points.
author: daveweigel

text:
The biggest R-D swing in Michigan!

2014 gov: R +26
2016 prez: R +3
2018 gov: D +4
author: daveweigel

text: One reason Rs are right to worry about the precedent of this emergency declaration is that it no way feels like we're living through an emergency. Compare that to how a Dem president could take advantage of, say, a hurricane engulfing Miami Beach.

text:
Bernie Sanders's campaign has recognized a union (w/ United Food and Commercial Workers Local 400), the first presidential campaign to do so.

This was a trend that began in 2018. @IronStache was first candidate to do it; @RepDebHaaland was first to do it and go on to win.
author: daveweigel

text:
Banning drugs makes them more popular, banning people on social media makes them fade out of public memory.

People keep mixing up the two for some reason.

text: Serious Q here: Do you think that social media networks acted wrongly in banning Milo? Now that we've seen how the bans ended his career as a public figure?

text: More candidate speeches should be carried live. Networks have crews there (most of the time) and, unless there's breaking news, all they're interrupting is a panel talking about what the candidates are saying.

text: The whole video of Beto's first Iowa stop is worth watching. Twitter jokes are one thing, but the gushy coverage was based on something: He is very very good in a town hall. He, Warren, Buttigieg, and Klobuchar have the most natural skill I've seen.
